title: Warren presidency, tech stock repricing ahead: Saxo
text:
Nate Silver, who uses statistics to analyse US elections, said Ms Warren's rise reflects the taking of a little bit of support from each of the other main Democratic presidential contenders.

Mr Jakobsen said a Biden v Trump election would be about "two old men fighting it out over who is the most macho", while a battle of Warren v Trump "brings an enormous contrast of not just substance, but also style and persona".

Both Warren and Trump are "populists", Mr Jakobsen argues, and their common ground includes being pro-tariffs and against a strong US dollar.

"To the modest degree that Trump won the election despite losing the popular vote by millions, he did bring a consistent message of slashing taxes, cutting red tape" and deregulation, Mr Jakobsen said. "These are all things that the markets love.

"In contrast, Senator Warren’s agenda reads: We need to take back democracy, rebuild the middle class, and end corruption in Washington, mainly by taxing the rich and attacking the big corporate monopolies."

Mr Jakobsen argues that Ms Warren will attract more women and younger voters, and she also speaks to both low- and middle-class Americans - and she does so in a way that she offers "something very different" which is what many voters are seeking.

"The economic situation between now and election will deteriorate at least until Q2-2020 and by then even a ‘deal which is de facto a non-deal’ with China will not be able to change Ms Warren’s rise," Mr Jakobsen said. "Senator Warren is a 'momentum stock' while Trump is a more of a slow moving 'dividend stock'."

Advertisement

Mr Jakobsen predicts that President Trump will be impeached though he'll have enough Republican support in the Senate to avoid being forced from office. Still, the impeachment process will take a lot of energy out of him and "the trade war and his never ending ‘playing loose with the facts’ will ultimately catch-up with him", he also said.

"The market impact will be heavily negative for technology companies – the FANGS, but it will also play into our Q4 Outlook: The Killer Dollar as Warren, like Trump strongly advocates a weaker Dollar."

Mr Jakobsen said he predicts that Mr Biden’s candidacy will "wither away" over the next few months and when the momentum of Senator Warren’s rise is more clearly registered by the market, there will most likely be a repricing of technology stocks, and even the dollar.

"For now the consensus thinks that Biden can beat Trump but Warren can’t. But that consensus ignores the tectonic demographic and political shifts in the US, the fact that the US’ largest generation, unlike every single other Developed Market country outside of Canada, is the Millenenial generation, who are now the deciders if they are motivated to get out and rock the vote next November."
description: Saxo chief economist Steen Jakobsen is predicting that Elizabeth Warren will be the 46th US president, and that will be bad news for the FANGs.
